cryptidSeen.cryptidDescription: The Jersey Devil is described as having horse hooves on its back legs, talons on its front legs, bat-like wings, and devil horns and tail. It seems to be able to walk on two legs.

accountOfSighting.descriptionOfAccount: During the week of January 16-23, 1909, footprints were spotted in the snow through the Delaware Valley. These footprints were assumed to be the Jersey Devil because they were hoofprints that appeared to be from a two-legged horse.

mediaSource.mediaDescription: This article goes into the history and origin of the Jersey Devil, as well as the week in January 1909 that had caused multiple states in the North East to discuss what these footprints could be, and if they were from the Jersey Devil.

sightingLocation.locationDescription: The sightings in the Delware Valley span across multiple states, including New Jersey, Delaware, and Pennsylvania. The Delaware Valley follows the Delaware River.

mediaEvidence.mediaName: The Jersey Devil, the tale of a viral story from 110 years ago
mediaEvidence.mediaDescription: This article revists the sighting 110 years after the fact, including newspaper articles from the time.

evidenceAffirmative.evidenceDescription: Multiple newspaper clippings with photographs of the footprints and reports of sightings.

mediaEvidence.mediaName: The Jersey Devil, the tale of a viral story from 110 years ago
mediaEvidence.mediaDescription: This article also delves into how journalists at the time could be more lenient with what they reported on and could easily be bribed.

evidenceNegative.evidenceDescription: Journalists who can be bribed into reporting on something that is not real led to a week-long hunt for the Jersey Devil
